choices.text: Annual new case detection rate per lac
Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

questions.text: A public health official is evaluating the effectiveness of a health system in emphasizing early detection of leprosy in a community setting. Which of the following metrics would be most indicative of the system's commitment to early identification?" [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade 2 disability is useful in determining whether the health system is giving importance to identifying leprosy in the community.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment completion rate: This measures the effectiveness of treatment adherence and success but does not directly reflect the system's ability to detect cases early.

 

Option B. Annual new case detection rate per lac: While it shows the number of new cases detected, it doesn't indicate how early these cases are being detected.

 

Option C. Treatment initiation rate: This measures how quickly diagnosed patients begin treatment but does not indicate how early the cases are being detected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability is a key indicator of the effectiveness of a health system in detecting leprosy early.
  • Lower proportions suggest better early detection efforts

questions.text: A nurse removes her latex gloves contaminated with blood and bodily fluids after a procedure. According to biomedical waste management guidelines, into which colored bag should she place the used gloves for disposal? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Red

 

  • Latex gloves contaminated with blood and other bodily fluids are considered contaminated waste (recyclable) and should be disposed of in red-colored bags or containers.
  • This category includes items like tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), and gloves.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: As a physician on a disaster preparedness committee in a region prone to natural disasters, you are discussing the appropriate sequence of actions following a disaster. Which of the following sequences correctly represents the appropriate steps in disaster management after the event has taken place? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Response – Rehabilitation – Reconstruction – Mitigation – Preparedness

 

The correct sequence after a disaster as per the general disaster management principles is:

 

  1. Response: Immediate actions taken to ensure safety, provide emergency services, and stabilize the situation. This involves –
    • Search, rescue and first aid
    • Field care
    • Triage
    • Tagging
    • Identification of dead
  2. Rehabilitation: Short-term recovery and normalization of operations to restore basic services and functions in the affected area.
  3. Reconstruction: Long-term rebuilding of infrastructure and restoration of a fully functional community.
  4. Mitigation: Efforts to reduce the risk and lessen the impact of future disasters.
  5. Preparedness: Planning and preparation to improve response activities for future disasters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disaster Cycle

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient undergoes a pacemaker replacement procedure at a tertiary care hospital. The surgeon successfully replaces the pacemaker and hands over the used device to the nursing staff for proper disposal as per biomedical waste management guidelines. According to the guidelines for biomedical waste management, in which colored bag should the used pacemaker be discarded? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Blue

 

  • According to biomedical waste management guidelines, used pacemakers, which are considered metal waste, should be disposed of in blue-colored containers or cardboard boxes marked with blue.
  • This ensures that the device is appropriately handled, disinfected, and sent for recycling or other safe disposal methods.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In case of a prior history of neural tube defects, women in the preconception period should be advised to take: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Folic acid

 

Folic acid is crucial for women in the preconception period, especially for those with a prior history of neural tube defects (NTDs). Neural tube defects are serious birth defects that affect the brain and spinal cord. The neural tube forms early in pregnancy, and folic acid, a B vitamin, plays a significant role in preventing these defects.

 

For women with a prior history of NTDs, the recommended dose of folic acid is higher than usual—4 milligrams (mg) per day. This higher dose is necessary because these women are at a greater risk of having another pregnancy affected by NTDs. Ideally, folic acid supplementation should begin at least 3 months before conception to maximize its protective effect.

 

This intervention is considered a form of primary prevention because it is aimed at preventing the occurrence of NTDs in pregnancies where the risk is already known due to a previous history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron is important during pregnancy, but it does not have a direct role in preventing neural tube defects. It is typically recommended for preventing anemia.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D is crucial for bone health and immune function, but it is not specifically related to the prevention of neural tube defects.

 

Option D. Calcium: Calcium is vital for bone health, particularly for the developing fetus, but like iron and vitamin D, it is not involved in the prevention of neural tube defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For women with a prior history of neural tube defects, folic acid supplementation at a dose of 4 milligrams per day should be started at least 3 months before conception as a form of primary prevention.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the operation and management of Mobile Medical Units (MMUs)? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. MMUs are run by the government
  2. MMUs are run by external agencies with medical supplies given by the government.
  3. MMUs are run by the government and medical supplies are also given by the government.
  4. MMUs are run by external agencies and medical supplies are also given by the external agency.
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1, 2, and 3

 

  • MMUs can be operated by either the Government or an external agency; however, the availability of drugs and medical supplies is exclusively the responsibility of the Government.
  • Mobile Medical Units (MMU) represents a significant project within NRHM, aimed at delivering a variety of healthcare services to individuals residing in distant, hard-to-reach, unserved, and underserved regions, encompassing both rural and urban locations.
  • The goal is to bring essential healthcare services directly to the residents in these areas.

 

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

 

  1. Government operated MMU
  2. MMU operation is outsourced to an external agency, while the government covers capital expenses, medication, and supplies.
  3. External agency outsourcing includes both capital and operational expenses for MMUs.

 

The government is responsible for providing medication and supplies. MMUs offer essential primary healthcare services for prevalent illnesses (both communicable and non-communicable), reproductive and child health (RCH) services, screening examinations, and necessary referrals to advanced facilities and specialists. Medical Officer-led clinical services are delivered by a team, while mobilization and outreach activities are undertaken by ANMs and ASHA personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Services and Resources of MMUs:

 

  • MMUs offer a variety of services, including primary care for common diseases, reproductive and child health services, diagnostic screenings, and referrals to specialized care.
  • They are equipped with facilities for basic diagnostic tests such as blood glucose monitoring, pregnancy testing, and sputum sample collection, among others.
  • Human resources typically include a medical officer, a nurse, a lab technician, a pharmacist/administrative assistant, and a driver/support staff.

choices.text: It is a type of droplet infection
Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease
Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness

questions.text: All of the following are TRUE about Rubella infection, EXCEPT? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease

 

Rubella infection in the 1st trimester: 90% have a significant risk for abortion and severe congenital malformations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a type of droplet infection:  This statement is true. Rubella is transmitted via respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Vertical transmission is possible:  This statement is true. Rubella can be transmitted from the mother to the fetus.

 

Option D. Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness:  This statement is true. While the risk of severe congenital malformations is lower in late pregnancy, the fetus may still be affected, with deafness being a potential outcome.

 

Educational Objective :

 

RUBELLA

 

Cause → RNA Togavirus

 

IP → 14-21 Days

 

Source → Cases [No carriers - No Iceberg phenomenon]

 

Mode of Transmission → Resp. [Air droplets]

 

Period of Communicability → 1 week before rash ← SYMPTOMS → 1 week after rash

 

Vaccine → Live attenuated RA 27/3 strain [C/I in pregnancy]

 

1st priority group → Non pregnant Non Lactating Reproductive 15-49 yrs female [1st trimester]


Congenital Rubella Syndrome → CVD [PDA], Cataract, Sensory Neural Deafness

 

Most common and most dangerous time for transmission of Rubella from Mother to Child is First trimester

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing district data to determine which areas should be prioritized for tuberculosis (TB) interventions. According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), which of the following HIV-TB prevalence rates would categorize a district as high-priority? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) >10%

 

  • According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), districts are categorized based on specific criteria to prioritize TB interventions.
  • One of these criteria is the prevalence of HIV-TB co-infection.
  • High HIV-TB Prevalence: A district is categorized as high-priority if more than 10% of TB patients tested are known to be HIV positive.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: One basic health worker per 10,000 population
Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

questions.text: The Chadah committee suggested all of the following options except: [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) One PHC for 50,000 population 

 

  • The correct answer, "B. One PHC for 50,000 populations," refers to a recommendation actually made by the Kartar Singh Committee, not the Chadah Committee. 
  • The Chadah Committee was established to assess the necessary arrangements for the Maintenance Phase of the National Malaria Eradication Program (NMEP). 
  • It emphasized integrating vigilance operations of the NMEP within general health services, specifically through PHCs at the block level, and allocating health workers specifically for malaria vigilance, among other public health tasks.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You're a physician attending a conference on emerging infectious diseases. As the discussion shifts towards the recent outbreaks in South India, the speaker displays an image showcasing the life cycle of a specific virus. A fellow physician sitting beside you, being relatively unfamiliar with the recent disease trends in South India, asks for your insights about the virus in question. Given the depicted life cycle and the associated clinical syndromes, which of the following viruses would be the most likely culprit? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Nipah virus

 

NIPAH Virus

 

  • Genus: Henapi virus
  • Transmission in India:
    • Occurrence: West Bengal, Kerela (Kozhikode district)
    • Route: Consumption of fruits contaminated with bats (Pteropus: ‘Flying foxes’) secretions (person - person in India) 
    • Direct contact with infected bats, infected pigs, infected people
  • Clinical presentation: Encephalitis
  • IP is 4-14 days
  • Case fatality rate: 50%
  • Vaccine: NONE for humans
  • Treatment: Intensive supportive care
    • High-risk contacts and healthcare workers, who are under quarantine and monitoring for 21 days
  • WHO included Nipah virus under list of Emerging Diseases likely to cause Major Epidemics 
  • Comes under Category C of Bioterrorism agent 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Japanese encephalitis: Transmitted by mosquitoes and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Option B. Zika virus: Transmitted by mosquitoes, primarily the Aedes species, and does not match the transmission cycle shown in the image.

 

ZIKA VIRUS LIFE CYCLE

 

 

 

Option C. Rabies: Transmitted through the bites of infected animals (typically dogs or other mammals) and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nipah virus, transmitted through fruit bats and causing encephalitis, fits the transmission cycle shown in the image and is a significant emerging infectious disease in regions such as Malaysia and Bangladesh.

questions.text: Dr. Raghav, a young infectious disease specialist, is posted at a busy ICTC clinic in New Delhi. An anxious 30-year-old man walks in after being diagnosed HIV positive. He recalls a close contact having TB a year ago and is worried about his own health. Remembering the NACO guidelines, Dr. Raghav decides to counsel the patient and screen him for TB before symptoms manifest. This proactive approach by Dr. Raghav falls under which category of prevention? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Primary, secondary

 

Here in the above question, counselling for a disease comes under primary prevention. Simultaneously screening for a specific disease comes under secondary prevention.

 

PRIMARY PREVENTION:

 

It is an action taken prior to the onset of disease which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur.

 

Modes:

 

  • Health promotion like health education, environmental modifications, lifestyle and behavioural changes.
  • Specific protection like contraception, Vaccinations.

 

This is applied when risk factors are present but disease has not yet taken place.

 

SECONDARY PREVENTION:

 

It halts the disease progress and prevents Complications.

 

Modes:

 

  • Early diagnosis example sputum smear exam for AFB.
  • Treatment example DOTS, MDT.

 

It is applied when disease has possibly set in and it arrests the process of progression.

 

This dual approach ensures that the patient is both informed about preventive measures and assessed for early signs of TB, addressing risks before they manifest into more serious health issues.

 

Other Option:

 

TERTIARY PREVENTION: It includes disability limitation/prevention of further disability or death. his type of prevention aims to manage clinical diseases in order to slow or stop disease progression, reduce complications and restore function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The integration of primary and secondary prevention methods offers a holistic approach to patient care, especially in managing health in patients with complex needs like those living with HIV. This strategy not only seeks to prevent the onset of new diseases (like TB) but also to manage potential health issues proactively before they develop into more serious conditions.

questions.text: In a village, it is observed that several farmers have crossed gait and use a stick for support to stand up and walk. Due to poor yield from farms, they consume meals containing rice and pulses only. Supplementing their diet with which of the following vitamins could have prevented this? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Vitamin C

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of neurolathyrism. Vitamin C is beneficial in cases of lathyrism.

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings

  • Osteolathyrism (Odoratism): In animals

     

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine’ (BOAA)

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which type of graph is used to illustrate studies on healthcare and disease prevalence in a population? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Ishikawa diagram/Fish bone diagram

 

Explanation

 

Ishikawa Diagram/Fish Bone Diagram/ Cause & Effect Diagram:

 

Description: A visual tool that helps trace a problem’s cause back to its roots, creating a branched diagram that looks like a fishbone.

 

Application: Used to identify, explore, and display the possible causes of a particular problem, particularly useful in quality control and prevention strategies in healthcare.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Bar Diagram:

 

Description: Bar diagrams use bars of varying lengths to represent data. Each bar corresponds to a category with a specific quantity.

 

Application: Useful for comparing quantities across different categories, such as the number of cases in different disease categories or patient counts in various demographic groups.

 

Option B. Histogram:

 

Description: A histogram is similar to a bar chart but is used for continuous quantitative data divided into bins or intervals. It helps in understanding the distribution of data.

 

Application: Commonly used to show the distribution of a dataset, such as the age distribution of patients suffering from a specific disease or the distribution of blood pressure readings in a population.

 

Option C. Multiple Regression Model:

 

Description: Not a graph, but a statistical technique that models the relationship between a dependent variable and multiple independent variables.

 

Application: Used to predict outcomes based on several variables, such as predicting patient outcomes based on age, treatment type, and pre-existing conditions.

 

Educational objectives : Fishbone diagrams are instrumental in root cause analysis, helping healthcare teams systematically investigate the contributory factors leading to health issues or outbreaks.

questions.text: Which of the following International Health agencies is aiding in building toilets in India? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) FORD Foundation

 

Explanation:

 

The Ford Foundation has been active in India for several decades, supporting various initiatives aimed at alleviating poverty and promoting social justice. While the foundation's primary focus areas include public administration, urban planning, food security, women's empowerment, and inclusive education, it has also supported community-led initiatives that contribute to improved sanitation and public health. For instance, the foundation has partnered with local organizations to enhance living conditions in rural areas, which encompasses efforts to improve sanitation facilities

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red Cross: The Red Cross primarily focuses on disaster relief, emergency assistance, and health services but is not specifically known for aiding in the construction of toilets in India.

 

Option C. CARE: CARE has supported the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program in India but is not known for its involvement in building toilets.

 

Option D. USAID: The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) has been involved in various development projects in India, including health and sanitation initiatives. However, in the context of direct involvement in building toilets, the Ford Foundation's contributions are more prominently documented.

 

Educational Objective:

 

International Organization supporting specific programs - 

 

  • SIDA – TB
  • DANIDA – Blindness 
  • UNICEF – GOBI FFF campaign, applied nutrition program 
  • USAID – Technical Cooperation mission; supported SBM (Swatch Bharat Mission)
  • Rockefeller foundation – hookworm problem control & elimination; borehole latrines and establishment of AIIHPH (All India Institute of Hygiene and Public Health)
  • Colombo plan – Establishment of cobalt therapy unit (with the help of Canada) and AIIMS, New Delhi was established with financial assistant from New Zealand
  • FORD foundation – supporting sanitation initiatives in India, including the construction of toilets, to improve public health and living conditions. Also helped in establishment of NIHFW (National Institute of Health and Family Welfare) and RHTC (Rural Health and Training Centres)
  • CARE Foundation – Supported ICDS Program

questions.text: A 30-year-old resident physician was exposed to HIV through a needlestick injury and has come to the emergency department seeking help. You decide to start her on post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). Which of the following drug combinations is most recommended for PEP in this scenario? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir for 4 weeks 

 

  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is an emergency treatment for HIV exposure, typically recommended to be started as soon as possible after exposure, ideally within 2 hours and no later than 72 hours.
  • The choice of antiretroviral therapy for PEP should be guided by current recommendations that prioritize effectiveness and tolerability.
  • Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir (Option B): This combination is currently recommended for PEP due to its high efficacy, good tolerability, and strong safety profile. Tenofovir and Lamivudine provide a potent backbone of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), while Dolutegravir acts as an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI), which has a rapid onset of action and is well-tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis HIV

 

Preferably within 24 hours. Maximum within 72 hours.

 

Duration of prophylaxis is 28 days

questions.text: As per the Factories Act of 1948, what is the maximum permissible weekly working hours, inclusive of overtime? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 60 hours

 

The Factories Act of 1948 permits a maximum of 48 hours of regular work per week, which can be extended up to 60 hours per week with standard overtime.

 

Factories Act – established in 1948:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defence, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48 hours per week or less than 9 hours per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maximum work hours per week is 48 hours. With overtime one can extend it upto 60 hours.

questions.text: Calculate the median from the given set of observations: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 4, 8. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4.5


The median is the middle value of a data set when arranged in ascending order. For an even number of observations, the median is found by taking the average of the two middle numbers. In this set, the values in ascending order are: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. Since there are 8 values (an even number), the two middle values are 4 and 5. The median is calculated by averaging these two values:

 

Median = (4+5)/2 = 4.5

 

Educational Objective:
 

For an even number of observations, the median is the average of the two middle values when the data set is arranged in ascending order.

choices.text: Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance
90% of patients will be benefitted by giving the drug
90% of test results could have occurred by chance

questions.text: An investigative study was conducted in Mumbai wherein a promising new antihypertensive medication was evaluated for its potential efficacy. Initial clinical trials with a diverse cohort of patients with chronic hypertension revealed promising results in managing elevated blood pressure levels. The efficacy of the drug was measured meticulously, and upon analyzing the data, a p-value of < 0.10 was documented. Given this statistical information and considering the nuances of research interpretation, which of the following statements best elucidates the implications of this p-value in terms of the drug's effect? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance

 

  • A P-value of less than 0.10 suggests that the likelihood of the drug's benefits occurring due to chance is no higher than 10%.

 

 INTERPRETATION:

 

  • Out of 100 repeated tests, a statistically insignificant difference will occur only 10 times, while a statistically significant difference will emerge 90 times.
  • There is a 10% probability of incorrectly concluding that a drug is beneficial when it is not, which can happen in statistical studies when deciding whether to accept or reject a null hypothesis.
  • The P value is compared to a predetermined threshold value 'a'; if the P value is less than 'a', the test is considered statistically significant, and the null hypothesis is rejected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The p-value is a statistical parameter used to evaluate whether the results of an experiment are statistically significant.
  • In this case, a p-value of < 0.10 suggests there is up to a 10% chance that the observed benefits from the antihypertensive drug could be due to random variation rather than a true effect of the drug.

questions.text: A lactating mother is eating only vegetables. Which nutrient deficiency will be seen in her newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12

 

Explanation: In this scenario, the lactating mother is following a plant-based diet, consuming only vegetables. Vitamin B12 is a nutrient that is not found in plant sources, making it a potential deficiency for strict vegetarians. As a result, the newborn of this mother is likely to experience a deficiency in vitamin B12.

 

While vitamin D is another nutrient that lacks plant sources, it can be synthesized in the skin through exposure to sunlight. Therefore, a deficiency in vitamin D is less likely in this case compared to vitamin B12.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) is available in various plant-based sources, such as leafy green vegetables, legumes, and whole grains. Therefore, a deficiency in vitamin B2 is less likely in this scenario.

 

Option B. Vitamin A can be obtained from plant sources in the form of provitamin A carotenoids, which are found in yellow, orange, and green leafy vegetables. As the mother is consuming vegetables, a vitamin A deficiency is less likely.

 

Option D. Iron is present in several plant-based sources, including legumes, whole grains, and leafy green vegetables. While the bioavailability of non-heme iron from plant sources is lower than heme iron from animal sources, a deficiency is less likely if the mother consumes a varied vegetable-based diet.

 

Educational Objective

 

Vitamin B12 is a nutrient that is not found in plant sources, making it a potential deficiency concern for individuals following a strict vegetarian or vegan diet, including lactating mothers and their newborns.

questions.text: A 35-year-old nurse in a busy city hospital is focused on infection control for general respiratory illnesses. Regular hand washing with soap and water or using an alcohol-based hand rub is recommended to prevent the spread of infections. This recommendation falls under which level of prevention? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Primary

 

This is an example of primary prevention as the risk factor is already present but the disease is being prevented by handwashing. Primary prevention aims to prevent the onset of illness before the disease process begins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primordial:

 

  • Focuses on preventing the development of risk factors themselves, often through policy or societal changes.
  • For example, promoting a healthy lifestyle to prevent the development of high blood pressure.

 

Option C. Secondary:

 

  • Involves early detection and prompt intervention to prevent progression.
  • For example, screening programs like Pap smears for early detection of cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Tertiary:

 

  • Involves managing and reducing the impact of an ongoing illness.
  • For example, providing cardiac rehabilitation after a heart attack to prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levels of prevention

 

  • Primordial-Prevention of development of risk factors
  • Primary- Risk factor is present, but disease is being prevented.
  • Secondary-Disease is already present. Screening/early diagnosis and treatment is done in order to prevent the complications.
  • Tertiary- Complications are present, death is being prevented.

choices.text: Not given after 6 months of age
Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine

questions.text: All are true about Rotaviral vaccine except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Not given after 6 months of age

 

The Rotaviral vaccine is included in the National Immunization Schedule of India and is primarily available in two types: Rotavac and Rotasil.
 

 

Note -

 

  • The vaccine is typically given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age under NIS, with the possibility of extending the schedule up to 12 months in cases of delayed immunization.
  • Both vaccines are live attenuated, but VP8 subunit vaccine is also available, offering more strain specificity and showing good results in infants, adolescents, and adults.

 

However, it is incorrect to state that the vaccine is "Not given after 6 months of age," as it can be administered up to 12 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subunit vaccine: This statement is true as there is a subunit vaccine for rotavirus, specifically the VP8 subunit V protein vaccine, which has shown good results in various age groups.

 

Option C. Oral route of administration: This is correct. Rotaviral vaccines are given orally.

 

Option D. Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine: This is also correct. Rotavac is a monovalent vaccine, and Rotasil is a pentavalent vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rotaviral vaccine can be given up to 12 months of age according to the National Immunization Schedule of India.

choices.text: Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, skewed with outliers
Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers
Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, normal with outliers
Skewed with outliers, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal

questions.text: What information is conveyed by the graph presented below? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers 

 

The given Box and Whisker plot depicts different types of data distributions:

 

  1. Normal distribution - The median is in the middle of the box, with whiskers of equal length.
  2. Positively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the bottom of the box, with a longer whisker on the upper end.
  3. Negatively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the top of the box, with a longer whisker on the lower end.
  4. Normal distribution with outliers - The median is in the middle of the box, with equal whisker lengths and the presence of outliers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Box and Whisker plot

 

  • A graphical presentation of Numerical Data through its quartiles.
  • It has a box in the center and two wishers in its sides.
  • The box has got 2 ends, Quartile 1 (Q1) & Quartile 3 (Q3)
  • The vertical line inside the box is called median also known as Q2. The whole data is divided into 4 Quartiles
  • The lower end of one whisker represent the minimum value of the distribution.
  • The higher end of other Whisker represents the maximum value of the distribution.

questions.text: Which parameters would you utilize to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programmer? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Annual Blood Examination Rate

 

Annual blood examination rate (ABER): (Index of operational efficiency)

 

 

 

ABER is a critical parameter used to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Program. It reflects the proportion of the population that is being tested for malaria and helps determine the operational efficiency of the surveillance system. High ABER indicates effective surveillance and control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Annual parasitic incidence (API): Sophisticated measure of malaria incidence in a community

 

 

Option C. Slide positivity rate (SPR):

 

 

Option D. Slide falciparum rate: specifically measures the proportion of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum, the most severe form of malaria. It indicates the burden of P. falciparum in the population.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A community with a population of 20,000 documented 456 births in a year, of which 56 were stillbirths. The total number of deaths in the community for that year was 247, including 56 deaths within the first 28 days of life and 34 additional deaths after 28 days but before completing the first year of life. What is the infant mortality rate (IMR) for this community? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 225

 

 

In the given question, out of total 456 births, 56 were dead born. 

 

Therefore, the number of live births= 456-56 = 400.

 

In the same year, it is given that the number of deaths before 28 days is 56, and the number of deaths after 28 days but before 1 year is 34.

 

Hence, the total number of deaths of children < 1 year is 56 + 34 = 90

 

IMR = (90x1000)/400 = 900/4 = 225

 

Hence, the IMR is 225 per 1000 live births.

 

INFANT MORTALITY RATE

 

  • It is the number of deaths per 1000 live births of children under one year of age. It is the most sensitive indicator of availability and utilization of health care services in a country. Is most important indicator of health status of a community, level of living and effectiveness of MCH services in general. 
  • IMR is among ‘the best predictors of state failure’
  • It is a rate.
  • IMR of India (2023): 26.6 per 1000 live births; 
  • IMR of India - 35 per 1000 live births (NFHS-5 2019-21,); 28 per 1000 Live births (SRS, May 2022)
  • Is the second best indicator of socio-economic development of a country: Ultimate solution for lowering IMR lies in socio-economic development [Best indicator is U5MR]

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for the community, calculated as the number of infant deaths per 1000 live births.
  • This rate serves as a crucial indicator of the health status and effectiveness of maternal and child health services in the community.

 

NOTE - UNICEF considers U5MR or CMR as ‘single best indicator of socio-economic development and well-being’ (even better than IMR)

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman, recently employed in a textile factory in Ludhiana, Punjab, comes for her first antenatal checkup at 8 weeks of gestation. She inquires about the duration of maternity leave according to the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act of India. How long can she expect to be on maternity leave? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 26 weeks and 4 weeks after commencing

 

Under the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act of India, the maternity benefit includes:

 

  • 100% of wages for 26 weeks of leave for delivery.
  • 6 weeks of leave for abortion or loss of the baby.
  • 4 weeks of leave for any medical condition affecting the pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Employees State Insurance (ESI)

 

It comes under the Ministry of Labour. It is not applicable for Defence Mining and Railway.

 

People with a monthly wage of less than Rs.21000/month are eligible to get the benefits.

 

The benefits include the following:

 

  • Medical Care
  • Sickness benefit (70% wages for 91 days or 3 months)
    • If extended it becomes (80% of wages for 2 years)
    • Enhanced sickness benefit (100% of the wages for sterilization procedures – 7 days for males and 14 days for females)
  • Disablement benefit is 90% wages depending on temporary or permanent disability.
  • Dependent’s benefit is also 90%
  • Under ESI Funeral expense 15,000 is also given

questions.text: A district in Madhya Pradesh has CBR 19/1000 LB and CDR is 6/1000 LB. Find the annual growth rate of the district. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1.3%

 

The annual growth rate of a population is calculated using the formula:

 

Annual Growth Rate (AGR) = Crude Birth Rate (CBR) − Crude Death Rate (CDR)

 

In this case:

 

  • CBR = 19 per 1000 live births
  • CDR = 6 per 1000 live births

 

AGR = 19−6 = 13 per 1000

 

To express this as a percentage (which is the standard form for growth rates), you multiply by 0.1:

 

13 × 0.1 = 1.3%

 

Therefore, the annual growth rate for this district is 1.3%.

 

Additional Information –

 

  • Mid-year population is refer to the 1st of July.
  • India is in Stage 3 of Demographic cycle

 

Educational Objective:

 

The annual growth rate of a population is calculated by subtracting the Crude Death Rate (CDR) from the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) and then expressing this difference as a percentage.

questions.text:
You are employed at a primary health center (PHC) located in an area with a high risk of earthquakes. What actions would you take to ensure readiness for potential emergencies? [NEET PG 2022]

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Follow instructions given over the phone or radio by higher officials
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1,2,3

 

To ensure readiness for potential emergencies in a high-risk earthquake area, the following actions are crucial:

 

  1. Disaster Preparedness: Ensuring all financial and other resources are available. This involves mobilizing funds and resources for quick evacuation and emergency response.
  2. Increase Public Awareness: Conducting campaigns and using loudspeakers to inform the public about earthquake preparedness measures and safety protocols.
  3. Conduct a Simulation: Performing disaster simulations and assessing the response to identify areas for improvement and ensure the effectiveness of the emergency plan.

 

These steps are essential components of a comprehensive disaster preparedness strategy and done by someone working in a PHC situated in a high seismic zone. A medical officer is supposed to provide instructions by any communication method possible to manage through the calamity.

 

Roles and responsibilities of medical officer of PHC when posted in Seismic areas

 

  • Ensure funds and resources are available and can be mobilized at the time of disaster for quick evacuation
  • Preparedness to handle emergency
  • Disaster simulation practices and then check the response

 

Other Options:

 

While following instructions from higher officials is important during an actual disaster, it is not a proactive preparedness measure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency preparedness is a programme of long-term development activities whose goals are to strengthen the overall capacity and capability of a country to manage efficiently all types of emergency. It involves the following steps:

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Evaluate the risk of disaster
  5. Information sessions coordination with news media
  6. Adopt standards and regulations

questions.text: Which one of the provided thermometers is employed for measuring low air velocity as opposed to the cooling potency of the air? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Kata thermometer 

 

Kata thermometer is used to measure low air velocity rather than the cooling power of the air. It works by measuring the temperature difference between two thin wires heated to different temperatures in a moving air stream. The faster the air moves, the greater the temperature difference between the two wires, allowing the Kata thermometer to measure air velocity.

 

Other Options

Option B. Globe Thermometer: Measures mean radiant temperature, which is the average temperature of all the surfaces surrounding a particular point. This is useful in assessing thermal comfort in environments.

 

Option C. Wet Globe Thermometer: Used to measure heat stress by taking into account temperature, humidity, wind speed, and solar radiation. It is commonly used in the Wet Bulb Globe Temperature (WBGT) index.

Option D. Dial Thermometer: Measures air temperature using a dial indicator. It is a general-purpose thermometer and not specifically designed for measuring air velocity.


Educational Objective:

questions.text: In Indian health care system, PHC are divided into Type A and Type B PHCs. Number of deliveries in Type A PHC: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Less than 20

 

In the Indian health care system, primary health centers (PHCs) are categorized into Type A and Type B based on the number of deliveries performed per month.

 

  • Type A PHCs handle less than 20 deliveries per month
  • Type B PHCs manage 20 or more deliveries per month.

 

This classification helps in resource allocation and planning to ensure adequate maternal and child health services are provided at the PHC level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Indian health care system, Type A PHCs are those that handle less than 20 deliveries per month, while Type B PHCs manage 20 or more deliveries per month.

questions.text: A 40-year-old nurse in the infectious diseases ward is reviewing the necessary precautions for attending to patients with various primary diagnoses. For which of the following patients would she NOT need to take special airborne precautions? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Herpes Zoster 

 

  • While Herpes Zoster (shingles) can be contagious, it primarily requires contact precautions unless disseminated or in the immunocompromised, where it might necessitate airborne precautions if there are pulmonary symptoms.
  • Generally, for localized shingles in an immunocompetent patient, standard precautions along with contact precautions are sufficient, thus not routinely requiring airborne precautions like the diseases listed in the other options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Requires airborne precautions due to the high risk of transmission through airborne particles, particularly the respiratory droplets that can suspend in the air for extended periods.

 

Option C. Measles: Highly contagious and spreads through airborne transmission. Airborne precautions are essential due to measles' ability to remain airborne for up to two hours after the infected person has left the area.

 

Option D. Chicken Pox (Varicella): Also spread through airborne transmission, requiring similar precautions to measles to prevent the spread of the virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Measles, Tuberculosis, and chickenpox require airborne transmission precaution unlike herpes zoster.
  • The patient should be made to wear a mask for source control.
  • A fit-tested NIOSH-approved N95 or higher-level respirator should be used by the healthcare personnel whilst care delivery.

questions.text:
An internist in India is seeing a patient from a minority cultural and linguistic group. To foster therapeutic alliance and provide the best care possible, which of the following approaches should the physician prioritize? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

  1. Insist on good communication.
  2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter.
  3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions.
  4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception.
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

To foster a strong therapeutic alliance and provide high-quality care, the physician should prioritize the following:

 

1. Insist on good communication: Effective communication is crucial for building a strong doctor-patient relationship. Good communication helps in understanding the patient's concerns, explaining medical conditions and treatment options clearly, and ensuring that the patient feels heard and respected.

 

4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception: Culturally competent care involves acknowledging and respecting the patient's cultural, religious, and linguistic background. This approach ensures that care is tailored to meet the specific needs and values of the patient, which can enhance their comfort and trust in the healthcare system.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter: Incorrect. While good communication is essential, insisting on communication only via an interpreter may not always be necessary or preferred by the patient.

 

3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions: Incorrect. Treating patients regardless of their cultural perceptions does not align with providing culturally competent care, which aims to respect and incorporate cultural differences into the care plan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The communication skills of physicians are an effective step of making effective relationship between doctor and patient
  • Research has shown that the way patients perceive their connection with their physician significantly influences their sense of satisfaction and level of concern about their health
  • The goal of culturally competent health care services is to provide the highest quality of care to every patient, regardless of race, ethnicity, cultural background

questions.text: In which of the following analyses is monetary benefit quantified? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cost benefit analysis

 

Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA): CBA is a method used to evaluate the total costs versus the total benefits of a project or decision in monetary terms. It helps determine whether the benefits of a project or decision outweigh the costs, thereby justifying the investment. This type of analysis assigns a monetary value to all outcomes, allowing for a direct comparison between costs and benefits. For example, the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) might report that it saved $12 million in a given year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cost Effective Analysis (CEA): Definition: CEA assesses the relative costs and outcomes (effects) of different courses of action.

 

  • Output: It is measured in non-monetary terms such as health outcomes (e.g., quality-adjusted life years (QALY) saved). For instance, the NTEP might measure its effectiveness by the number of lives saved or the improvement in the quality of life.

 

Option C. Network Analysis: Definition: This is a quantitative method that involves mapping out and analyzing the sequence of activities and events in a project.

 

  • Tools: It includes techniques like Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) and Critical Path Method (CPM).
  • Usage: Network analysis is used to identify the sequence of tasks, the longest path through the project (critical path), and to optimize the project schedule.

 

Option D. Input Output Analysis: Definition: This method examines the relationship between inputs and outputs in an economic system.

 

  • Application: It can include both cost-benefit and cost-effective analyses as it calculates the effects of changing inputs on the outputs. This type of analysis is often used in economics to understand how different sectors of an economy interact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CBA [Cost Benefit Analysis] - Results of a program analyzed in terms of MONETARY benefits, e.g. NTEP (2023-24) saved 12 m US $

 

CEA [Cost Effective Analysis] - Output of a program analyzed in terms of RESULTS eg. NTEP (2023-24) save 1.7 Million people can be determined with help of QALY.

 

INPUT-OUTPUT ANALYSIS - Calculation of effects of changing the inputs (Includes CBA & CEA)

 

NETWORK ANALYSIS – It is a quantitative method. It includes activities & events. PERT is sequence of activities. CPM is the longest path in PERT.

choices.text: 3 Lac IU

questions.text: Under the guidelines used in India, the dose of Vitamin A for 1-3 years old is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 Lac IU

 

Explanation:

 

According to the immunization schedule and the older Vitamin A prophylaxis program in India, the recommended dose for children up to 1 year of age is 1 lakh international units (IU). For infants below 6 months of age, a dose of 50,000 IU is administered.

Once a child crosses the age of 1 year, the dose increases to 2 lakh IU. This dosage is applicable for toddlers, adolescents, and adults, and is used for both prophylaxis and treatment of Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. 50,000 IU: This dose is recommended for infants below 6 months of age.

 

  • Option B. 1 Lac IU: This dose is given to children up to 1 year of age.

 

  • Option D. 3 Lac IU: Not recommended under the guidelines of Vitamin A prophylaxis program.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For children aged 1-3 years, the recommended dose of Vitamin A under Indian guidelines is 2 lakh international units (IU).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits a clinic in Mumbai for a consultation about family planning. She discusses various options and services with her healthcare provider. During the conversation, she asks about additional health screenings included in family planning services. Which of the following screenings is NOT typically included as part of family planning services in India? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Screening for HIV infection

 

  • Family planning services aim to support individuals and couples in managing their reproductive health, but not all health screenings are integrated into these services:
  • Screening for HIV infection: This screening, while crucial for overall health and particularly important in prenatal care to prevent mother-to-child transmission, is generally conducted as part of broader sexual health services rather than within the narrower scope of family planning services.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening for cervical cancer: This is typically included because it directly relates to reproductive health and can impact a woman’s long-term health and fertility.

 

Option B. Providing services for unmarried mothers: This includes counseling and support, reflecting a comprehensive approach to reproductive health care that supports all individuals, regardless of marital status.

 

Option D. Providing adoption services: Part of family planning services that helps individuals and couples prepare for parenthood, including the option of adoption, aligning with the broad goals of family planning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Family planning is not synonymous with birth control only. A WHO Expert Committee (1970) recommends that family planning includes in its’ purview:

 

  • Proper spacing and limitation of birth
  • Advice on sterility
  • Education for parenthood
  • Sex education
  • Screening for pathological conditions related to the reproductive system (e.g., cervical cancer)
  • Genetic counselling
  • Premarital consultation and examination
  • Pregnancy tests
  • Marriage counselling
  • Preparation of couples for the first child
  • Providing services to unmarried mothers
  • Teaching home economics and nutrition
  • Providing adoption services

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with chronic liver disease is evaluated using the Child-Pugh score, which categorizes patients into classes based on disease severity. Which type of data does the Child-Pugh scoring system represent? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ordinal

 

  • The Child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity and prognosis of chronic liver disease by categorizing patients into different classes based on specific criteria.
  • This score assigns patients to Class A, B, or C based on their total points, indicating varying levels of disease severity and prognosis.
  • It is an ordinal scale of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal: Incorrect. Nominal data involves categories without order, which does not apply to the ordered nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Option C. Qualitative: Incorrect. While the Child-Pugh score is qualitative in describing severity, the specific classification into ordered categories makes it ordinal.

 

Option D. Metric: Incorrect. Metric data involves quantitative measurements with consistent intervals, which does not describe the ordinal nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following are types of polysaccharide vaccines except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hepatitis B

 

Hepatitis B is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant type of subunit vaccine, which means it is made using genetic engineering techniques to produce the surface antigens of the Hepatitis B virus

 

Other Options:

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are designed to elicit an immune response specifically against the polysaccharides found on the surface of certain bacterial capsules. These vaccines include:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae B (Hib) vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

These vaccines may also be available as glycoconjugate vaccines, which are designed to improve immunogenicity, especially in younger populations. However, the vaccine for Salmonella Typhimurium (Typhim VI) is available only in a polysaccharide form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B is a recombinant subunit vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine. Polysaccharide vaccines include those for pneumococcus, meningococcus, and Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Note - Polysaccharide vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies specifically against the polysaccharide components of the bacterial capsule. These polysaccharides are unique to particular strains or serotypes of bacteria, making the vaccine effective in targeting those specific types.

 

Limitations of Polysaccharide vaccines: serotype-specific and do not facilitate herd immunity due to their lack of a robust T-cell response.

choices.text: Mode is affected by extreme values
Mean is affected by extreme values
Median is calculated by overall observations
Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false for descriptors of central tendency? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Mode is affected by extreme values

 

  • Extreme values in a given dataset do not influence the mode.
  • Mode is the most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution.
  • It is uninfluenced by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mean is affected by extreme values: This is true. Extreme values (outliers) can significantly affect the mean, making it an unreliable measure of central tendency in skewed distributions.

 

Option C. Median is calculated by overall observations: This is true. The median is determined by arranging all observations in order and finding the middle value, or the average of the two middle values if the number of observations is even.

 

Option D. Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor: This is true. The mode is applicable to qualitative data as it represents the most frequently occurring category or value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mode is not affected by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data.
  • In contrast, the mean is affected by extreme values, and the median is a robust measure of central tendency that is calculated using overall observations.

questions.text: In a recent community health survey in Rajasthan, India, there has been a significant surge in cases of oral and lung cancers. It was found that tobacco consumption, both smoking and chewing, was a significant contributor. The government implemented legislation to curb tobacco use. This action is an example of which level of prevention? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Primary

 

The introduction of an Act to prevent the use of tobacco in community is an example of primary prevention, as it prevents the disease by bringing about a change of lifestyle, that is the use of tobacco as in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primordial:

 

  • Prevents the development of risk factors.
  • Example: Legislation to reduce tobacco use, promoting healthy lifestyles from a young age to prevent the development of harmful habits.

 

Option C. Secondary:

 

  • Involves early detection and prompt intervention to prevent progression.
  • For example, screening programs like Pap smears for early detection of cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Tertiary:

 

  • Involves managing and reducing the impact of an ongoing illness.
  • For example, providing cardiac rehabilitation after a heart attack to prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Level of Prevention:

 

  • Primordial - Prevention of development of risk factors
  • Primary - Risk factor is present, but disease is being prevented.
  • Secondary - Disease is already present. Screening/early diagnosis and treatment is done in order to prevent the complications.
  • Tertiary - Complications are present, death is being prevented.

questions.text: What is the observational unit in ecological investigations? [NEET PG 2018]

questions.text:
A healthcare worker in a remote primary healthcare clinic is reviewing the Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) on a vial of a vaccine that has been stored in the clinic for some time. Which of the following statements regarding the utility and interpretation of the VVM is/are correct?" [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare.
  2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat.
  3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine.
  4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM.
  5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is in an acceptable range.
  6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 2

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.

 

Other Options:

 

3. A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.

 

4 & 5. Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.

 

6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: As a young pediatrician practicing in India, you attend various workshops and training sessions to keep yourself updated with the latest guidelines in child health. questions.text: A bubonic outbreak has occurred within the community. What is the responsible vector for this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Xenopsylla cheopis

 

Xenopsylla cheopis, commonly known as a rat flea, serves as the carrier for the bubonic plague. This particular flea species can be recognized by its distinctive conical-shaped head, along with a thorax, abdomen, and three sets of legs.


 

  • Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis.
  • The reservoir of infections is wild rodents.
  • Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague.
  • Human plague mainly presents as:

 

 

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. There is fever along with painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes.

 

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague.

 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Species Phlebotomus argentipes: belongs to the group of sand fly. It transmits kala azar. Other diseases transmitted by sand flies are sandfly fever and oriental sore.

 

Option C. Ixodes Tick: transmits Lyme’s disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi.

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito transmits malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea) is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis. Understanding the vector and transmission routes is crucial for controlling and preventing outbreaks.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is NOT transmitted by sandflies? [AIIMS MAY 2019]

Ans. (d) Trench fever

 

Trench fever is transmitted by lice and caused by Bartonella quintana.

 

Points to remember about Sandfly - 

 

  • Sandfly cannot fly; it hops
  • Sandfly rests in cracks and crevices of walls
  • Insecticide of choice: 

 

DDT - 2 rounds of spray per year; Spray up to 6 feet height on walls; 

 

If DDT–resistant, use BHC 

 

  • Sandfly is the vector of:
    • Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala azar) (by Female Phlebotamus argentipes)
    • Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (Oriental Sore) & Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis (by Phlebotamus papatasi & Phlebotamus sergenti)
    • Sandfly Fever
    • Oroya Fever
  • Sandflies inject the infective stage, metacyclic promastigotes, during blood meals.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vectors and Diseases Transmitted

choices.text: It’s administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh
A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication
Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age
The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy experienced symptoms of a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a slight fever. Upon examination, the presented clinical image is visible. Which of the following sentences is false regarding the vaccine that could have prevented this condition? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication

 

A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication: This is false. A prior adverse reaction with a temperature above 40 degrees Celsius is a contraindication, not 37 degrees Celsius. Minor reactions, such as a mild fever, are not typically considered a contraindication for future vaccinations.

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A.  It’s administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh: This is true. The DPT vaccine is typically administered intramuscularly on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh in infants and young children.

 

Option C. Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age: This is true. The whole-cell pertussis vaccine is generally not recommended for individuals over the age of 7 due to an increased risk of adverse reactions. Instead, the acellular pertussis vaccine is used in older children and adults.

 

Option D. The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose: This is true. The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is lower than in pediatric formulations to reduce the risk of adverse reactions while still providing adequate immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What significant error did the intern make while creating a banner on measures to prevent the spread of non-communicable diseases, as assigned by a group of doctors?  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shift from PUFA to trans-fat

 

The significant error made by the intern while creating the banner on measures to prevent the spread of non-communicable diseases was the recommendation to "Shift from PUFA to trans-fat."

 

The other options, such as banning smoking in public areas, restricting alcohol selling/consumption, and decreasing additive salt on food, are appropriate measures to prevent non-communicable diseases.

 

However, the shifting from polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) to trans-fats is incorrect, as trans-fats are one of the important risk factors for the development of non-communicable diseases. The recommendation should be to reduce trans-fat intake and promote the consumption of healthier fats like PUFA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ban smoking in public areas - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as smoking is a major risk factor for non-communicable diseases.

 

Option B. Restrictions on alcohol selling/consumption - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as alcohol consumption is a risk factor for conditions like coronary heart disease and hypertension.

 

Option D. Decrease additive salt on food - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as even prudent diet (a diet for dietary goal achievement) says the salt intake should be <5gm/day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The significant error made by the intern was recommending a shift from polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) to trans-fats, as trans-fats are known to increase the risk of non-communicable diseases, contrary to the goal of preventing their spread.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman was admitted to a tertiary care hospital in New Delhi following a fall at home. During her stay, the nursing staff consistently followed protocols for waste segregation. Based on the guidelines for biomedical waste management, which type of waste should be correctly disposed of in the following mentioned bag? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Urine Bag

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anatomical waste: Anatomical wastes is disposed in yellow bin.

Option D. Sharp waste: Sharp wastes are disposed in white puncture proof, leak-proof, tamper-proof white containers.
