questions.text: Which of the options is considered the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Designated Microscopy Centre 

 

  • Among the given options, the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure is the Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC). This remains same for the new National TB Elimination Program 2020 too.
  • The DMC is the first point of contact for patients seeking diagnosis and treatment for tuberculosis (TB) and is responsible for collecting sputum samples and conducting smear microscopy to detect the presence of TB bacteria. The DMCs are established at the periphery level of the healthcare system, such as at the level of Primary Health Centers or Community Health Centers, to ensure that TB diagnosis and treatment services are accessible to people in their own communities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. District TB Centre: This option is higher up in the hierarchy than the DMC. It is responsible for the supervision and monitoring of TB control activities within the district, making it central but not the most peripheral.
 

Option B. Intermediate Reference Laboratory:  The IRL provides quality assurance for TB diagnosis and conducts drug susceptibility testing. It is a specialized facility that supports the network by confirming diagnoses and resistance patterns, placed higher in the organizational hierarchy than DMCs.
 

Option C. Tuberculosis Unit:  While the Tuberculosis Unit is responsible for providing treatment and care to TB patients, it is not as peripheral as the DMC. The TU operates within a more integrated role in patient management and care continuum than the DMC, which is strictly focused on initial diagnostics.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

The Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC) remains a foundational component in the RNTCP for its role in accessible, community-level TB diagnosis and initial management. Its position as the most peripheral center in the hierarchy underscores its critical function in early TB detection and intervention.

questions.text: Observe the image below showing different food items. Identify the source of Thiamine. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) B (Rice)

 

Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism and the proper functioning of the nervous system. The primary dietary sources of thiamine are whole cereal grains, meat, and fish. In the context of the image provided, the food item labeled "B" corresponds to rice, which is a significant source of thiamine.

 

Rice, particularly unpolished or whole rice, contains a high level of thiamine in its outer layer. However, polished rice, commonly consumed in many parts of the world, loses much of its thiamine content due to the removal of the outer layer during polishing. This loss is a contributing factor to thiamine deficiency in populations that primarily consume polished rice, leading to conditions such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, especially among chronic alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Cucumber and onion: These items are not significant sources of thiamine. Vegetables like cucumbers and onions contain very low levels of thiamine and are not considered a primary dietary source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Chapati/Flatbread: Chapatis are made from wheat flour, which does contain some thiamine. However, it is not as significant a source as rice, particularly in the whole grain form.

 

Option D. Dal/Lentil Curry: While lentils do contain some thiamine, they are not considered a primary source compared to whole grains like rice. The thiamine content in legumes is present but not in quantities significant enough to be considered the best option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rice, especially in its whole or unpolished form, is a significant dietary source of thiamine (Vitamin B1).

 

Other sources – Whole cereal, meat, fish, legumes, ground nut.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with intermittent episodes of severe colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and passage of currant jelly stools. The clinical suspicion is towards intussusception. Taking the child's immunization history, which recent vaccine could be associated with a slightly increased risk of this condition? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Rotavirus vaccine

 

Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a complication of intussusception.

 

ROTA virus vaccines

 

  • 4 Types – but 2 used in NIS
  • ROTAVAC and ROTASIL (live, att., lyophilized with diluent citrate bicarbonate buffer)
  • ROTAVAC →1 dose = 0.5 ml
  • ROTASIIL → 1 dose – 2.5 ml with 6 ml syringe
  • 3 doses – 6, 10, 14 weeks
  • Complication - INTUSSUSCEPTION

 

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not associated with intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a rare complication of intussusception, an important consideration when assessing an infant presenting with symptoms of this condition.

questions.text: The typical lifespan for a Japanese woman is 87 years. Due to recent progress in cervical cancer testing, her life expectancy has risen by 15 years. With a healthcare utility value of 0.8, what can be determined based on these provided parameters? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) QALY

 

Quality Adjusted Life Years (QALYs)

 

  • QALY is a measure of both quality and quantity of life lived
  • QALY is years of life lived in perfect health
  • QALY is used in assessing the value of money of a medical intervention
  • QALY calculation is simple: the change in utility value induced by the treatment is multiplied by the duration of the treatment effect to provide the number of QALYs gained

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HALE: Health-adjusted life expectancy - equivalent number of years in “full health” that a new-born can expect to live based on current rates of ill health and mortality

 

Option B. DALY: Is disability-adjusted life years, which is the best measure of disease burden, including both reduction in life expectancy and diminished quality of life. It can measure both mortality and disability together.

 

DALY = YLL (years of life lost) + YLD (years lost to disability)

 

Option C.  Sullivan’s Index, now called DFLE (Disability-free life expectancy): Means the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability (given the current mortality and disability). It is calculated as Life expectancy minus duration of disability

 

Educational Objective:

 

QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years) is the measure used to assess the value of medical interventions by considering both the quality and quantity of life lived. In this scenario, the increase in life expectancy due to cervical cancer testing and the given utility value are used to calculate QALYs gained.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man from west Garo Hill district of Meghalaya presents to the Civil Hospital with intermittent fever, chills, and malaise. Laboratory findings confirm the diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria. The region is known for its Multidrug- resistant strains of P. falciparum. Which of the following antimalarial regimens is considered the most appropriate first-line treatment for P. falciparum malaria in areas with multidrug-resistant strains? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Artemether plus lumefantrine

 

The Drug of choice treatment for Plasmodium falciparum infection in North Eastern states is artemether + lumefantrine

 

ARTEMISINS - ARTESUNATE AND ARTEMETHER

 

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 

 Artemisinin Combination Therapy [ACT]

 

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For P. falciparum malaria in regions with known drug resistance, artemether plus lumefantrine is the most effective first-line treatment, ensuring rapid and sustained clearance of the malaria parasite.

choices.text: Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presented with a 1-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest x-ray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ask for CBNAAT

 

According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) guidelines, the next step in managing a patient with a high clinical suspicion of tuberculosis (TB), a suggestive chest x-ray, and negative sputum smears is to perform a CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test). CBNAAT is a molecular test that detects the DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and can also identify rifampicin resistance, providing rapid and accurate results.

 

DIAGNOSTIC TESTS UNDER NTEP:

 

1. Sputum smear Microscopy

  • ZN staining
  • LED – FM

 

2. Culture

 

  • LJ Medium
  • Automated Liquid culture (ALC)
    •  BACTEC MGIT 960
    • BACTALERT
    • VERSATREK

 

3. Drug sensitivity testing

 

  • Moderate Proportionate Sensitivity testing PST MGiT 960
  • Economic proportionate sensitivity testing 1% LJ Medium

 

4. Molecular Diagnosis test:

  • Line Probe Assay
    • LPA TB
    • PL LPA– INH & Rifampicin Resistance
    • SL LPA-FQ / SLI Resistance
    • NAAT
    • CBNAAT
    • True NAT True NAT
  • Developed by ICMR Real time PCR Technology 
    • True NAT MTB- MTB
    • True NAT MTB plus- MTB
    • True NAT MTB Dx- Rifampicin Resistance TEP:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat sputum smears: Is not appropriate since the patient already had two negative sputum smears and a chest x-ray suggestive of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. CBNAAT: Should be performed first than Line probe assay.

 

Option D. TB: Culture takes time to yield results, the patient may deteriorate in the meantime.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A study on 100 urban women evaluates potential risk factors for breast cancer using odds ratios (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI). An OR > 1 with a CI not including 1 suggests a significant association. How many risk factors show a statistically significant association with breast cancer? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 3

 

In the above statistical group, the odds ratio of early menarche, BRCA mutation, and obesity show positive association and are statistically significant.

 

A high socioeconomic status does not pose a risk factor. Despite observing a positive correlation, the statistical significance is absent. Any correlation with a 95% confidence interval with the value of 1.0 is deemed as statistically insignificant. A value of 1.0 within this range implies that both factors can coexist without one being the cause of the other.

Odds ratio (OR) is the key parameter in case-control studies to assess the strength of association between the exposure and outcome. The interpretation of the odds ratio can be done as below:

 

  • OR > 1 indicates a positive association.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association.
  • OR < 1 indicates a negative (protective) association.

 

Interpretation of the individual factors given in the question:

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

There are three factors (early menarche, BRCA mutation, obesity), that have statistically significant associations with breast cancer according to the odds ratios and their 95% confidence intervals provided.

choices.text: In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive
Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease
Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease
Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease

questions.text: Among the following options, which statement accurately represents the relationship between prevalence of a disease and characteristics of a diagnostic test? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease

 

  • The accuracy of a screening test's positive predictive value (PP) relies on the disease's prevalence.
  • PPV, which stands for positive predictive value, signifies the chance that a patient showing a positive test outcome has indeed acquired the disease.
  • In other words, it represents the probability that an individual with a positive test result genuinely possesses the disease.

 

PPV of a screening test depends on:

 

  • Sensitivity
  • Specificity
  • Prevalence of disease in the population

 

PPV of a screening test is directly proportional to the prevalence of disease in the population

 

  • PPV α Prevalence of disease
  • As the prevalence of a disease increases in a population, PPV increases for the screening test

 

Sensitivity and Specificity are independent of the prevalence the of disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive: This is misleading because in populations with a low prevalence, a positive result from even a highly sensitive test could still be a false positive due to the low likelihood of the disease.

 

Option B. Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease and Option D. Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease Sensitivity and specificity are intrinsic characteristics of a test that are determined by comparing the test results against a gold standard and are independent of disease prevalence in the population being tested. They remain constant regardless of how common or rare the disease is within that group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The positive predictive value (PPV) of a diagnostic test is significantly influenced by the prevalence of the disease within the population.
  • PPV indicates the probability that individuals who test positive actually have the disease.

questions.text: Which among the following is not true according to case-control study? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cause to effect design

 

Explanation:

 

A case-control study is a retrospective study that looks backward in time, starting with the outcome (disease) and then investigating potential exposures or risk factors that may have contributed to the disease. It is an effect-to-cause study design. Case-control studies are particularly useful for studying rare diseases, as they allow researchers to identify a sufficient number of cases without requiring a large cohort.

 

Due to the retrospective nature of the study, incidence rates cannot be calculated directly. Instead, the strength of the association between exposure and outcome is measured using the odds ratio, which is calculated using the formula –

 

2 × 2 table

 

 

Odds Ratio (Cross Product Ratio) = ad/bc

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. "Effect to cause design" is a true statement about case-control studies, as they start with the disease (effect) and work backwards to identify potential causes (exposures).

 

Option B. "Used to study Rare Disease" is also a true statement. Case-control studies are well-suited for investigating rare diseases because they allow researchers to identify a sufficient number of cases without requiring a large cohort, which would be impractical and costly.

 

Option C. "Odds ratio can be calculated" is correct. In case-control studies, the incidence rate cannot be directly calculated, so the strength of the association between exposure and outcome is measured using the odds ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case-control studies are retrospective, effect-to-cause study designs that are particularly useful for investigating rare diseases and calculating odds ratios to measure the strength of association between exposures and outcomes.

questions.text: Researchers are monitoring two groups to assess the health impacts of an environmental factor, one exposed to the factor and the other not. They aim to compare the disease rates between these groups. Which study design is best for calculating the 'Relative Risk' or 'Risk Ratio'? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cohort

 

A cohort study is most appropriate for calculating the Relative Risk (RR), as it follows individuals over time to observe the incidence of disease in both exposed and non-exposed groups. This design allows for a direct comparison and quantification of the risk associated with the exposure.

 

RR (Relative Risk/ Risk Ratio):

 

  • RR= Incidence among exposed/Incidence among Non-exposed
  • Indicates strength of association.
  • Interpretation of RR:
    • RR = 1 No association
    • RR > 1 Positive association (The assessing factor is a risk factor)
    • RR < 1 Negative association (The assessing factor is a protective factor)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Using a cohort study enables researchers to effectively determine the effects of environmental exposures on health by tracking and comparing disease incidence over time in different groups.
